Content: You may additionally want to backup your wallet.dat, but as long as you have your seed phrase you can always restore after the upgrade, or after many upgrades, it is your lifetime key

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: @coingirl87 what I meant was that there is a command, that when you claim the rewards, these rewards are not sent to your main wallet, but to another wallet of your choice.

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: And then you dont mention the wallet where the intrest/rewards are sent to

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: So as far as the taxman knows, you dont have any rewards and thus dont have to pay taxes on the entire amount

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: Not sure what the command was, I’m sure @jl777c or one of the devs will know, I just know a feature like that exists and might be a solution to the problem.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: -donate=pubkey parameter on komodod when launched will send the rewards to the pubkey address

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: does the rewards sent after the start of the daemon?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no, it just sends rewards to the donation pubkey instead of the usual destination

Author: Tek#5253
Content: can anyone spoonfeed me on why KMD is better than ETH

Author: Tek#5253
Content: supose all mining coins stop, what happens with KMD?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: So whenever a txn is done, whatever is the reward that will be claimed by your address, will be sent to the `donation`  address automatically

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: @Tek dPoW is only the beginning. With it you get BTC level re-org protection. But beyond that, there is new tech in development that allows for cross-chain contracts based on notarization data.

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: kmd smartcontracts are utxo based and not balance based is one of the benefits I read often

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: so when there is a problem with your smartcontract, not your entire balance is at stake as it is with ETH where some contracts were completely whiped out because of a bug.

Author: Tek#5253
Content: nice

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with ETH a single popular dapp boosts gas fees for everyone on the network and maybe at some point it is just too expensive to use. that is one cats game. what if there are 100 such popular dapps? Actually, on ETH that is impossible. Just imagine what would happen if there were 100 dapps as active as cryptokitties...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with KMD, we had a KMDICE chain do almost a million tx in a day, paying txfees in KMDICE and no other KMD chain even noticed, since it is an independent chain. We can easily imagine 100+ independent chains, each with a dedicated dapp., actually there is no limit to the number of indepedent chains, since they are independent

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 10,000 chains, even more are possible

Author: Daniel CP#2020
Content: @Tek  ETH is one blockchain with support for smart contracts. So developers and entrepreneurs can easily build on ETH and create tokens or dApps. But they do not get a blockchain. They just get tokens or they get a dApp with shared infrastructure (because there is just one blockchain) and this leads to massive congestion, like jl777 said above.  Komodo is better because it's not a single blockchain, like ETH is. Komodo is a platform that gives every project their own blockchain, with independent infrastructure, no shared blockchain, no congestion. And, on top of all that, each chain launched with Komodo has support for smart contracts, tokens, dApps, etc. So basically every project that builds with Komodo is given an Ethereum platform to build with.

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: does KMD participate in the forming of the consensus of the pirateChain? What I'm trying to ask is, does the KMD chain snapshot the chain with most work, or is there some "magic" involved in figuring out what to snapshot?

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: Had a conversation with @PirateChain at twitter and he suggested I come here to ask these questions

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: also, sorry if KMD is not the correct term. I mean what ever the thing is, that provides dPoW for PirateChain

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: To clarify my question, say I managed to get enough hashpower to 51% attack the native PirateChain, say I decided to mine empty blocks or just transactions I wanted to include or what ever (assuming I'm not altering the consensus rules or anything like that), rest of the network would keep on operating like it's been doing before. Now say my version of the chain accumulates more work, does KMD snapshot my version of the ledger or is there something in the mix that can pick and choose which fork they consider valid?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: @lord kek the public chain will get notarized

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: @Alright What do you mean by public chain?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: which ever chain has consensus between the notary nodes will get notarized

Author: Alright#0419
Content: if that chain has someone mining empty blocks, it will get notarized

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: So if I only build on top of my own chain and manage to accumulate more work, mine will get notarized?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: if it's public

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: yeah, can be public for the purpose I'm asking for

Author: Alright#0419
Content: and doesn't try to rewrite a notarized block

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: Do you feel this changes the game theory of PoW compared to say btc?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: in regards to what

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: the incentives and attack vectors

Author: Alright#0419
Content: mining incentivize is the same as BTC other than notary's mining blocks as well

Author: Alright#0419
Content: it mitigates many attack vectors that BTC or a BTC fork has

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: I don't think it is the same tho

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: because btc has no limit to the number of block that can reorg

Author: Alright#0419
Content: sure it does

Author: Alright#0419
Content: there is a 99 block limit first of all

Author: Alright#0419
Content: and not enough hardware in the world to even accomplish that

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: as far as I understand, here the limit is on average 3 blocks?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: typically 10

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: So basically it's a sprint to reach most work for every 10 blocks and then the other side has no alternative but build on top of mine?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: basically

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: So, it's a cat and mouse game that resets every 10 minutes?

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: if that's the case, how is that the same as btc, where 99 blocks is 16.5 hours?

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: doesn't that change the game theory at all?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: what game theory in particular are you talking about

Author: Alright#0419
Content: from the perspective of a KMD miner vs BTC miner, not much difference

Author: lord kek#0511
Content: well with btc, the miners mining their fork is insentivized to protect the block rewards they have accumulated
